columns.text: In this problem, we will look at how additional investments and costs can affect the cash flow of the project in each year of its lifespan.

In the problem, we are given two additional values. The first is the net working capital of $\$250,000$ and the salvage value of $\$180,000$.

The net working capital refers to the amount of money invested in order to fund the initial proceedings of the project. This amount is added back at the end of the project since it assumes that all money invested are covered in the final profit. 

The salvage value refers to the amount an asset will be sold at the end of its lifespan or at the end of its use in the project.

Since a salvage value is already presented, the depreciation will then change. To solve for this, we will take the difference between the initial investment and the salvage value, then divide it by the number of years. We will then get:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Depreciation}&=\dfrac{\$2,320,000 - \$180,000}{3}\\[15 pt]
&=\$713,333.33
\end{aligned}$$

The asset loses $\$713,333.33$ in value every year.

At Year 0, the net cash flow is expected to be negative since this is the part of the project where the funding is being turned over. This means, our net cash flow can be solved by taking the sum of the net working capital and the fixed asset investment of $\$2,320,000$ and negating it. 

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Year 0 net cash flow}&=-(\$250,000+\$2,320,000)\\[15 pt]
&=-\$2,570,000
\end{aligned}$$

The net cash flow at Year 0 is $-\$2,570,000$
For the succeeding years, it is stated in the previous problem that the estimated annual sales is $\$1,735,000$. This means that we will use this in the computation for our taxes and the cash flow.

For the computation of the tax, we can simply take this annual sales and multiply it by the tax rate of $0.21$.

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Tax}&=\$1,735,000 \times 0.21\\[15 pt]
&=\$364,350
\end{aligned}$$

The tax for this every year is $\$364,350$

Subtracting the tax from the annual income, we will get the cash flow:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Cash flow}&=\$1,735,000-\$364,350\\[15 pt]
&=\$1,370,650
\end{aligned}$$

The cash flow is $\$1,370,650$. Take note that this will only apply to **Year 1 and Year 2** since there are additional factors in play in the finaly year which will make the cash flow different.

Additionally, we will use the present value factor for the cash flow. The present value factor adjusts the amount based on the required return. In this case, we will use the factor $0.71178$ as it is the corresponding factor for $12\%$ required return for $3$ years.

Multiplying the cash flow by this factor, we will get:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Present value cash flow}&=\$1,370,650 \times 0.71178\\[15 pt]
&=\$975,601.26
\end{aligned}$$

For **Year 1 and Year 2**, the present value cash flow is $\$975,601.26$

For **Year 3**, we will consider the salvage value of the asset. We will multiply the value by one minus the tax rate to solve for the after-tax salvage value.

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{After-tax salvage value}&=\$180,000\times(1-0.21)\\[15 pt]
&=\$142,200
\end{aligned}$$

To get the cash  flow for **Year 3**, we can simply add the cash flow in Step 7 and the after-tax salvage value, as well as the working capital as mentioned in Step 2.

The cash flow will then be:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Cash flow}&=\$1,370,650+\$142,200+\$250,000\\[15 pt]
&=\$1,762,850
\end{aligned}$$

Multiplying the present value factor to the answer above, we will get:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Present value cash flow}&=\$1,762,850 \times 0.71178\\[15 pt]
&=\$1,254,761.37
\end{aligned}$$

The present value cash flow for **Year 3** is $\$1,254,761.37$

Substituting the values, we will get:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Net present value}&=\dfrac{-\$3,000,000}{(1-0.12)^0}+\dfrac{975,601.26}{(1-0.12)^1}\\
&+\dfrac{975,601.26}{(1-0.12)^2}+\dfrac{1,254,761.37}{(1-0.12)^3}\\[15 pt]
&=\$1,209,705.01
\end{aligned}$$

The new net present value for this project is $\$1,209,705.01$
